text: Oh, we're starting. Oh, [LAUGHTER] okay.
How would you define the job of a Product Manager?
Well, really your job is to be right.
[MUSIC] But maybe we can break that down a little bit.
Be right a lot. [LAUGHTER] [MUSIC]
Product management has become central to our approach of teaching venture creation,
entrepreneurship, and innovation here at Stanford.
I'm Mike Lepech, I'm a faculty member in the School of Engineering here at Stanford.
I'd like to welcome you to this program for which I serve as academic director. [MUSIC]
So basically it involves setting a clear direction for your team,
understanding what it is you need to do,
sequencing to get there,
and doing everything it takes to get it done.
I think an important part of product management is making decisions,
and it's a trainable skill,
like, it's not magic.
You get comfortable making decisions by making a lot of decisions.
This is the reason that a lot of CEOs come out of product management.
You get trained on making lots of decisions really quickly,
and then you get better making decisions.
I think what's unique about this course is,
we have a combined 20 years of experience doing this in top Silicon Valley companies,
and we're not gonna give you
the theoretical frameworks we're gonna give you what reality actually looks like.
Like, what is the day-to-day?
What do you actually do?
Like, when you sort of imagine an alternate version of the textbook,
and this one is like actually doing it.
Yeah. So we will teach you the frameworks,
but the same time we'll give you a bunch of examples.
From a personal experience,
but also from a lot of people in the industry that we've worked with,
met, um, or had the fortune of connecting with.
I learned product management the hard way, through countless mistakes,
lots of late nights that turned into early mornings,
and a great deal of wasted time and money.
That's why I'm so excited that we're able to offer this program on Product Management.
So that you can learn directly from experienced product managers
and not have to repeat all mistakes that I learned so painfully.
One of the reasons that we are excited to make this class is we
haven't found any great resource for people on our team.
So this- the- the goal of this class is to really find
a scalable way to say what we wish we knew when we were getting into Product Management.
Yes. And we've also been teaching this for three years at Stanford,
and we wanted a way for this to scale beyond just the classroom.
Hundreds of people apply each year,
and we can only give 30 to 40 slots.
And with this, we want all of you guys to be able to take it.
We can't wait to see you online in our class.
See you soon. [MUSIC]
